questions.question: What does molecular evidence for evolution compare?
questions.explanation: Molecular evidence examines similarities and differences in DNA nucleotide sequences or protein amino acid sequences across species.

questions.question: How do DNA similarities support evolutionary relationships?
options: More similar DNA suggests closer kinship
All DNA evolves at the same rate
questions.explanation: Species that share a more recent common ancestor have accumulated fewer DNA mutations and therefore have more similar genetic sequences.

questions.question: What are conserved genes?
options: Genes found in one species only
questions.explanation: Conserved genes (like those for ribosomes or cytochrome c) are essential for basic cellular functions and mutate slowly, revealing deep evolutionary relationships.

questions.question: Why compare cytochrome c across species?
options: It is essential and evolves slowly
It is different in every organism
It is easy to extract from fossils
questions.explanation: Cytochrome c is a protein involved in cellular respiration. Its slow, steady mutation rate makes it useful for comparing distantly related organisms.

questions.question: What does a molecular clock estimate?
questions.explanation: A molecular clock uses mutation rates in DNA or proteins to estimate when two species last shared a common ancestor.

questions.question: How can molecular evidence confirm fossil evidence?
options: Both come from the same sources
questions.explanation: When molecular data (DNA/protein similarities) and morphological data (fossils/anatomy) produce similar phylogenetic trees, they reinforce each other as evidence.

questions.question: What might unexpected molecular similarities suggest?
questions.explanation: Sometimes DNA reveals close relationships not obvious from anatomy (e.g., whales being closely related to hippos), correcting earlier classifications.

questions.question: Why is ribosomal RNA (rRNA) often used in molecular studies?
options: It is present in all living things
It is easy to see under microscopes
questions.explanation: rRNA genes are found in all cellular life, are essential for protein synthesis, and evolve slowly enough to compare even very different organisms.

questions.question: How do pseudogenes provide evolutionary evidence?
questions.explanation: Pseudogenes are non-functional DNA copies of genes. Their similar mutation patterns in related species show common ancestry (e.g., vitamin C pseudogene in primates).

questions.question: What limitation exists in molecular evidence?
options: It doesn't work for extinct species without DNA
It only works for animals, not plants
questions.explanation: While powerful, molecular evidence requires preserved DNA or proteins, which are rarely available from fossils more than a million years old.
